'''''Lactarius pallidus''''' (also known as the '''pale milkcap''') is an [[edible mushroom]] of the genus ''[[Lactarius]]''. It is pale in colour, and found on the floor in [[beech]] or [[birch]] woodland. Its smooth [[pileus (mycology)|cap]] features a particularly thick layer of flesh, and often has an incurved margin. Though generally considered [[edible mushroom|edible]], it is not recommended to be eaten raw. It is common in [[Europe]], and less common in [[North America]] and [[Australasia]].

==Taxonomy==
''L. pallidus'' was classified as a member of ''Lactarius'' by Swedish mycologist [[Elias Magnus Fries]]. It was first described by [[Christian Hendrik Persoon]],<ref name="Phillips"/> who named it ''Agaricus pallidus''<ref>{{cite book |title= Bibliographical Index of North American Fungi - Vol I - Abrothallus to Badhamia|last= Farlow|first= W. G.|year= 2007|publisher= Read Books|isbn= 978-1-4067-2125-6|page= 143|url= https://books.google.com/books?id=MPxUbxv8oCEC&pg=PA143&vq=pallidus&dq=%22Lactarius+pallidus%22}}</ref> in his 1797 book ''Tentamen dispositionis methodicae Fungorum''.<ref name="May">{{cite web |url= http://www.rbg.vic.gov.au/dbpages/fungi/cat/details.php3?id=3397|title= Lactarius pallidus|accessdate=2009-02-09 |last= May|first= Tom|work= Interactive Catalogue of Australian Fungi|publisher=[[Royal Botanic Gardens, Melbourne]] and [[Australian Biological Resources Study]]}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref> It is known in English by its [[common name]], the pale milkcap.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.rogersmushrooms.com/gallery/DisplayBlock~bid~6291~gid~.asp|title= Lactarius pallidus|accessdate= 2009-02-09|last= Phillips|first= Roger|publisher= RogersMushrooms|url-status= dead|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20080906131314/http://www.rogersmushrooms.com/gallery/DisplayBlock~bid~6291~gid~.asp|archivedate= 2008-09-06}}</ref>

==Description==
[[File:Lactarius vellereus - Lindsey 1b.jpg|thumb|left|''L. pallidus'' gills]]
''L. pallidus'' has a [[pileus (mycology)|cap]] of {{convert|4|to|10|cm|in}} across. In shape, it is initially a flattened convex, developing a funnel-shaped depression with age. It is pale buff in colour, sometimes dull but often with rosy tint. It can also be a pale brown or pale flesh colour. The cap is smooth, firm and sticky, and has a thick layer of white to buff flesh. The margin is incurved on younger specimens.<ref name="Phillips"/> The pale colour, incurved margin and smooth cap are its most distinguishing features.<ref name="Pegler"/> The [[stipe (mycology)|stem]] is {{convert|3|to|8|cm|in}} long, by {{convert|6|to|28|mm|in}} thick. In shape, the stem is cylindrical or slightly narrowed at the base, and is concolorous with the cap or whitish. The moderately decurrent, crowded gills are a pale rosy buff to yellowish buff, and leak white [[latex|milk]]. The spores are elliptic, with ridges of varying thickness running across them, forming few cross-connections. They typically measure 8 to 10 by 6 to 7 [[micrometre]]s. The spores leave a [[spore print]] that is pale ochre with a slight salmon tinge.<ref name="Phillips">{{cite book |title= Mushrooms and Other Fungi of Great Britain and Europe|last= Phillips|first= Roger|year= 1981|publisher= [[Pan Books]]|location= London|isbn= 0-330-26441-9|page= 83}}</ref>

''L. pallidus'' is similar in appearance to ''[[Lactarius affinis|L. affinis]]'', but is differentiated by the fact that the former lacks the peppery taste of the latter.<ref name="McKnight"/>

==Edibility==
Though generally considered edible,<ref>{{cite book |title= British Edible Fungi|last= Cooke|first= M. C.|year= 2007|publisher= Read Books|isbn= 978-1-4067-5608-1|page= 230|url= https://books.google.com/books?id=lOrahbcWdKAC&pg=PA230&dq=%22Lactarius+pallidus%22}}</ref> especially after cooking,<ref name="Phillips"/> ''L. pallidus'' has been described by some mycologists as inedible.<ref name="Pegler">{{cite book |title= Mushrooms and Toadstools|last= Pegler|first= David N.|year= 1983|publisher= Mitchell Beazley Publishing|location= London|isbn= 0-85533-500-9|page= 115}}</ref> The milk has a mild to moderately hot taste.<ref name="Phillips"/>

==Distribution and habitat==
''Lactarius pallidus'' is typically found growing [[mycorrhizal]]ly under [[beech]], but can also be found under [[birch]].<ref name="Pegler"/> It is typically half-buried among [[leaf litter]].<ref name="Pegler"/> It can sometimes be found in large groups,<ref name="Pegler"/> and occurs throughout summer and autumn.<ref name="Phillips"/> It can be found commonly in [[Europe]] but is much rarer in [[North America]].<ref name="McKnight">{{cite book |title= A Field Guide to Mushrooms, North America|last= McKnight|first= Vera B.|author2=Peterson, Roger Tory |year= 1998|publisher= [[Houghton Mifflin Harcourt]]|isbn= 978-0-395-91090-0|page= 326|url= https://books.google.com/books?id=kSdA3V7Z9WcC&pg=RA1-PA326&dq=%22Lactarius+pallidus%22}}</ref> It can also be found in [[Australia]].<ref name="May"/>
